section.title: Introduction
section.para: This chapter provides instructions for installing &sr;.
&sr; is officially compatible with two platforms: SGI and Linux. lists the recommened system requirements.
&recommendations;
describes the minimum software requirements for building &sr;.
&requirements;
On Linux systems (Mandrake 9 and Red Hat 8), &sr; binaries may be installed via RPM (Red Hat Package Manager). Alternatively, &sr; binaries may be built and installed from source code tarballs.
On SGI systems &sr; binaries must be built and installed from source code tarballs.
Be sure to read section after installing but before starting &sr;.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: You must have root privilages to install &sr;. Contact your system administrator if you don't.
The following procedure installs &sr; in /usr/local/SCIRun/bin.

section.title: Downloading
section.para: Obtain the appropriate &sr; rpm, either SCIRun-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm for Mandrake 9 systems or or SCIRun-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm for Redhad 8 systems. Be sure to get DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz too. These files can be downloaded from SCI's software archive page.

section.title: Installing &sr;
section.para:
Become superuser:
su Password:
Cd to the directory where &sr; was downloaded and type:
rpm -ivh SCIRun-x.x.x-mdk9.0.i586.rpm
or
rpm -ivh SCIRun-x.x.x-rh8.0.i386.rpm
shows this process (assuming /tmp is where the rpm was downloaded). Type exit to leave the root account.

section.title: Unpacking Sample Data Sets
section.para:
Unpack &sr;'s sample data sets by typing:
tar zxf DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz
This will create SCIRunData, a directory containing sample data sets.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Python (version 1.5.2 or later) and GNU make (version 3.79 or later) must be present before proceeding with the tarball installation.

Installation from tarballs consists of these steps:
Downloading (compressed) tarballs containing &sr; sources, packages, third party software, and sample data sets.
Unpacking the tarballs.
Building and installing third party software.
Building &sr;

listitem.para: Obtain the source code for SCIRun and any desired packages. Be sure to get the Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.tar.gz and DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz files too. The compressed tarballs for these sources can be downloaded from SCI's software archive page.

Unpack the &sr; tarball in a directory of your choice:
gunzip -c &sr;.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create a directory called &sr;. Below we use the term &sr; when referring to this directory (ignoring its full pathname).

Unpack the compressed package tarballs into &sr;/src/Packages, for example:
gunzip -c BioPSE.PKG.x.x.x.tar.gz | (cd &sr;/src/Packages && tar xf -)
to unpack the BioPSE package.

note.title: Note
note.para: discusses a method for putting the downloaded &sr; sources under control of the CVS version control system. This is useful if you will be writing modules or other &sr; code. This is not a requirement for installing &sr; though!

listitem.para:
Unpack the tarball containing sample datasets:
gunzip -c DataSets.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create the directory SCIRunData.

Unpack the third party tarball:
gunzip -c Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.tar.gz | tar xf -
This will create the directory Thirdparty_install.x.x.x.

section.title: Building Third Party Software
section.para: Third party software must be built before building &sr;. Follow these steps:

listitem.para:
cd to the third party software directory:
cd Thirdparty_install.x.x.x

Run the third party installation script:
python install dir 32|64 jobs
where dir is the directory in which the third-party software will be installed (although it is actually installed in a sub-directory of the specified one), 32|64 specifies one of 32 bit or 64 bit binaries, and jobs is the number of jobs that make will create when building the software. For example:
python install /usr/local/&sr;_Third_Party 64 2
or
python install /usr/local/&sr;_Third_Party 32 1
When finished, the installation script will display the complete name of the third-party software installation directory—make note of this value.
listitem.note: The name of the third-party installation directory reflects the parameters given to the install script. This allows you to maintain multiple third-party installations for different operating systems and machine architectures.
listitem.para: You may reinstall part or all of the third-party software by repeating the previous command. You will be asked to replace all or part of the installation. Just answer y or n to the script until you have selected the exact reinstallation you wish.

Run &sr;'s configure script. This can be done from the &sr;/src directory:
cd &sr;/src ./configure --with-thirdparty=third-party-dir \ --enable-package="package-name1 package-name2 …"
or from another directory, for example a sub-directory of &sr;:
mkdir &sr;/dir cd &sr;/dir ../src/configure --with-thirdparty=third-party-dir \ --enable-package="package-name1 package-name2 …"
in which case &sr; will be built in the directory &sr;/dir (where dir is a directory name). Above, third-party-dir is replaced by the name of the third party software installation directory and "package-name1 package-name2 …" is replaced by a list of (previously downloaded and unpacked) package names , e.g. "BioPSE MatlabInterface". For example:
../src/configure --with-thirdparty=/usr/local/&sr;_Third_Party/1.4.2/Irix/CC-32bit \ --enable-package="BioPSE"

It is useful to run the configure script from directories other than &sr;/src so that you can build multiple versions of &sr; from a single source directory. For example, you may wish to build a Linux version and 32 bit and 64 bit Irix versions. Assuming &sr; resides on a volume shared by all machines you may do this:
mkdir &sr;/linux mkdir &sr;/sgi32 mkdir &sr;/sgi64
Then, after logging onto the Linux machine:
cd &sr;/linux ../src/configure options
Then from the Irix machine(s):
cd &sr;/sgi32 ../src/configure options cd &sr;/sgi64 ../src/configure --enable-64bit options
There are many options to the configure command in addition to the --with-thirdparty and --enable-package options you have already seen. lists many of them.

Run (GNU) make from the directory used previously when running configure (e.g. &sr;/linux, &sr;/sgi32, or &sr;/sgi64). Note that the configure directory will be called build_dir from now on.
cd build_dir make
Be sure that make invokes GNU make. GNU make may be named gmake or gnumake on your system.

For a multiprocessor system you can use GNU make's -j option to reduce the build time:
make -j N
where N is the number of processors available for use by make. Using this option on a multiprocessor machine will often significantly reduce the time to build &sr;.

section.title: Preparing &sr;
section.para: Before starting &sr; you should initialize the environment variables SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR and SCIRUN_DATA.

section.subtitle: Dynamic Compilation
section.para: Before executing &sr; you should be aware of a feature called Dynamic Compilation.

Dynamic compilition is a technique used by &sr; that discovers and generates code for the data types and algorithms used by modules in your networks. This is done at runtime and is done once for each new data type and algorithm encountered. This technique provides a number of benefits not discussed here.

By default, code generated by dynamic compilation is stored in the directory build_dir/on-the-fly-libs. The location of dynamically generated code can be changed (and doing so provides a number of benefits—see below) by setting the value of the environment variable SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR to the desired directory, for example:
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=$HOME/on-the-fly-libs; export SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR
for Bourne-like shells (sh, ksh, bash, etc.) or
setenv SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR $HOME/on-the-fly-libs
for csh-like shells.

It can also be changed by setting the value of this variable in your .scirunrc file. Your .scirunrc file would contain, for example:
SCIRUN_ON_THE_FLY_LIBS_DIR=/home/me/on-the-fly-libs
Your .scirunrc file is read by &sr; at startup.

Customizing the value of this variable for each &sr; user has the following benefits:
It allows multiple users to run the same instance of &sr; (at the same time) without worrying about dynamic compilation conflicts. For example, by specifying an on-the-fly-libs directory in their home directory, a user can run the same shared &sr; installed in /usr/local that another user is already running.
It allows a /usr/local installation of &sr; to be secure by not requiring that /usr/local/…/on-the-fly-libs be writable by all (which is considered a potential security risk).
It allows greater debugging and multiple build support by allowing the user to change dynamically compiled code locations between instances of &sr;.

SCIRUN_DATA specifies the default data directory of &sr; data sets. Initially you will want to set it to point to the sample data sets directory, SCIRunData:
export SCIRUN_DATA=/path/to/SCIRunData
or
setenv SCIRUN_DATA /path/to/SCIRunData

section.title: Starting &sr;
section.para: After a successful build, build_dir will contain the scirun executable. To start &sr; type ./scirun. &sr;'s network editor window should appear and the &sr; shell should start.
If the window does not appear note any errors displayed in the &sr; console and see .
See the &sr; Users Guide for particulars on the use of &sr;.

section.title: Getting Help
section.para:
Subscribe to the &sr; users list. Use it to get answers to your installation and use questions. To subscribe send email to: majordomo@sci.utah.edu with the following in the body of the message (no subject):
subscribe scirun-users
To ask a question send email to: scirun-users@sci.utah.edu

Be sure to include a verbatim (cut and paste) copy of any errors displayed. Also include a short description of what you we're doing (running a network, building the tree, etc.) and which version of &sr; you have.
See also the FAQs
